description:
I've spent some time trying to update the structure of the docs to be simpler and more easily navigable. I've also updated several items that appeared out of date. I'm hoping that this will address some of the recent comments regarding the docs in the yt community survey, but I know we have a long way to go and that it will take work by many other developers.

A brief summary of the things I addressed in this PR here:

* Added an Introduction section to the front page.  It is a brief blueprint of the code/docs, so that people know what fields really are, why we have data objects, why to use filters, derived quantities, derived fields, etc.
* Added an About section with basic contact information, citation information, and history of the code.
* Put the FAQ on the main page. Added several items to the FAQ and divided it up into topic headers.
* Unlinked the Intro to Python section from the references. I'm not totally averse to having this, I just don't know where to put it. Perhaps at the end of the Intro to yt section?
* Brought the Analysis Modules section to the main page as Topic-specific analysis modules and renamed Analyzing section to General Analysis. [WILL DO IN SEPARATE PR]
* Updated yt 3 differences to explicitly provide steps for updating 2.x scripts to 3.0 status.
* Cleaned up header of main page to provide direct links to what codes are supported, how to get sample data, and how to load that sample data.
* Adding docs for enable_parallelism() as I said I would in PR #1340
* Added table of contents to all major pages
* Added more descriptive headers in viz docs so it's easier to find things for the new user who doesn't know our jargon (slices, volume rendering, etc)
* Added more description on how to install rockstar with yt since it had previously said it was installed by default.
* Added documentation on known issue described in Issue #959 re: Ray's having non-continuous data representation.
* Adding a number of FAQ entries on various topics (units, common errors, etc.)
* Documenting (and linking the docstrings) for the differences between the two ``add_fields()``
* Adding header descriptions to all pages of the docs.

I've included a quick build of these docs here: http://chummels.org/yt/index.html

Once this gets added, I will move the analysis modules to the front page in a subsequent PR.

UPDATE1: Implemented changes suggested by @ngoldbaum .
title: [DOCS] Structural and Content Docs Update (OMNIBUS)

content.raw: All tests pass. Good job!
content.html: All tests pass. Good job!

content.raw: As a quick note, there is likely a way to change how the analysis modules are located in the docs without actually moving them around, which might make it easier *next* time we want to change how they're listed.  I can help dig through to do that if you like.
content.html: As a quick note, there is likely a way to change how the analysis modules are located in the docs without actually moving them around, which might make it easier next time we want to change how they're listed. I can help dig through to do that if you like.

content.raw: You're right that this was a poor place to put this information.  Can you add a link here to the place where you've moved it in the unit system docs?
content.html: You're right that this was a poor place to put this information. Can you add a link here to the place where you've moved it in the unit system docs?

content.raw: Why not just `x.in_units('kpc')`?  If this is a raw numpy array multiplying by length_unit won't necessarily by the correct thing to do, unless the numpy array represents data in code units already.
content.html: Why not just x.in_units('kpc')? If this is a raw numpy array multiplying by length_unit won't necessarily by the correct thing to do, unless the numpy array represents data in code units already.

content.raw: Can you rephrase this to match the output from a python REPL session (i.e. using `>>>`).  Sphinx will do the correct thing.
content.html: Can you rephrase this to match the output from a python REPL session (i.e. using >>>). Sphinx will do the correct thing.

content.raw: Can you specifically link to the notebook that discusses this, instead of the unit system in general?
content.html: Can you specifically link to the notebook that discusses this, instead of the unit system in general?

content.raw: .value and .d have different semanitcs.  The former returns a copy, the latter returns a view.
content.html: .value and .d have different semanitcs. The former returns a copy, the latter returns a view.

content.raw: This FAQ should at least be updated to note that serialize = False is the default now/
content.html: This FAQ should at least be updated to note that serialize = False is the default now/

content.raw: Can you revert this to "how to make plots"?
content.html: Can you revert this to "how to make plots"?

content.raw: Yes, it is ready for full review.  The url I listed is the up to date version.
content.html: Yes, it is ready for full review. The url I listed is the up to date version.

content.raw: Yes, I'm talking about a raw numpy array here as opposed to a YTQuantity.  I don't see why this wouldn't work for what I'm suggesting--it multiplies by the correct conversion factor in the same way pf.units['kpc'] was, and it gives it the appropriate unit, thereby turning x into a YTQuantity.  When I test it out, it works fine.
content.html: Yes, I'm talking about a raw numpy array here as opposed to a YTQuantity. I don't see why this wouldn't work for what I'm suggesting--it multiplies by the correct conversion factor in the same way pf.units['kpc'] was, and it gives it the appropriate unit, thereby turning x into a YTQuantity. When I test it out, it works fine.

content.raw: Maybe just say that x needs to be interpreted as a scalar in code units?
content.html: Maybe just say that x needs to be interpreted as a scalar in code units?

content.raw: In looking through the units notebooks, I did not see one that ever discussed this, which is why I chose to link to the whole page.
content.html: In looking through the units notebooks, I did not see one that ever discussed this, which is why I chose to link to the whole page.

content.html: I can add that as a note, but I think providing this code snippet is very useful to a lot of people who are trying to convert their 2.x scripts to 3.0 scripts.
